Amalgamations of New Brunswick

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

You have new messages (last change).

The Canadian Province of New Brunswick's municipalities cover only 20% of its landmass, but 80% of its population. Many of those 102 municipalities have been created from amalgamations of several former municipalities, or by annexing unincorporated areas. Prior to several amalgamations that occurred in between 1991-1998, the province had well over 120 municipalities. There are now 102.

This article lists current municipalities in New Brunswick, and underneath, the former municipalities that form the new municipality are listed and the year they joined the new municipality if known. Unincorporated areas that joined municipalities are mentioned as well, if known. Explanations on the basis of the amalgamations are given wherever possible.

Contents

  • 1 Saint John Area
  • 2 Northern New Brunswick
  • 3 Charlotte County
  • 4 Southeast New Brunswick
  • 5 Central New Brunswick

[edit] Saint John Area

In 1997, the provincial government set out to lessen the number of municipalities in the Saint John area from 11 to 1. Due to staunch opposition from the ten municipalities outside of the city, amalgamation did occur, but larger towns were created instead of one huge city. The 3 new towns are Grand Bay-Westfield in the west, and Rothesay & Quispamsis in the Kennebecasis Valley, out east. The City of Saint John remained unchanged.

Town of Grand Bay-Westfield

  • Town of Grand Bay (1998)
  • Village of Westfield (1998)
  • Village of Pamdenec (1988).

Town of Quispamsis

  • Town of Quispamsis (1998)
  • Village of Gondola Point (1998)
  • eastern section of Wells, an unincorporated community (1998)

Town of Rothesay

  • Town of Rothesay (1998)
  • Village of East Riverside-Kingshurst (1998)
  • Village of Renforth
  • Village of Fairvale (1998)
  • western section of Wells (1998)

City of Saint John

  • Town of Carleton (1789)
  • Town of Parrtown (1789) (Parrtown & Carleton joined to form the first ever City of Saint John, which has grown many times since then.
  • City of Portland (1889)
  • Parish of Simonds (1967)
  • Parish of Lancaster (1967)
  • City of Lancaster (1967)

[edit] Northern New Brunswick

Town of Belledune

  • Village of Jacquet River (1994)

City of Miramichi

The following towns and villages, as well as countless rural unincorporated areas were amalgamated in 1995 to help the Town of Chatham after the air force base there closed down, greatly hurting the local economy. The result is the much larger City of Miramichi. Newcastle and Chatham, are the main communities, but other small municipalities were forced in as well.

  • Town of Newcastle (1995)
  • Town of Chatham (1995)
  • Village of Douglastown (1995)
  • Village of Loggieville (1995)
  • Village of Nelson-Miramichi (1995)

Town of Tracadie-Sheila

  • Town of Tracadie (1991)
  • Village of Sheila (1991)

Village of Perth-Andover

These two neighbouring towns in Victoria County joined shortly after Equal Opportunity created the "village" level of municipal government in New Brunswick.

  • Village of Perth (1967)
  • Village of Andover (1967)

City of Edmundston

The City of Edmundston grew greatly when in 1995, 3 neighbouring towns were forced together with Edmundston at the centre. The nearby Village of St-Hilaire was supposed to amalgamate as well, but the province changed their minds as it would make the geographical size of the new city too large.

  • City of Edmundston (1990s)
  • Town of St-Jacques (1990s)
  • Town of St-Basile (1990s)
  • Village of Verret (1990s)

[edit] Charlotte County

Town of St. Stephen

When St. Stephen and Milltown amalgamated, the town was called St. Stephen-Milltown, but the new name not having caught on, reverted to simply the Town of St. Stephen.

  • Village of Milltown (19??)-

Village of Grand Manan

The Island of Grand Manan consists of 2600 people. Before 1995, there were 3 municipalities, and 2 local service districts. The island joined together as one municipality in 1995 to eliminate the added costs of having 5 jurisdictions. The neighbouring island of White Head, which was unincorporated, remained as such, as it did not wish to join the larger island's municipality. It remains as the Local Service District of White Head Island.

  • Village of North Head (1995)
  • Village of Seal Cove (1995)
  • Village of Grand Harbour-Ingalls Head (1995)
  • unincorporated areas of Woodwards Cove & Castalia (1995)

[edit] Southeast New Brunswick

Village of Riverside-Albert

  • Village of Riverside (1966)
  • Village of Albert (1966)

City of Moncton

  • Village of Lewisville (19??)

[edit] Central New Brunswick

City of Fredericton

  • Town of Devon (1945)
  • Town of Marysville (1973)
  • Village of Barkers Point (1973)
  • Village of Nashwaaksis (1973)
  • Village of Silverwood (1973)
  • Garden Creek Local Service District (1973)
